newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australian Stocks to Watch Today - Feb 25.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australian Stocks to Watch Today - Feb 25.

text.p: Some Australian stocks to watch this morning:
Chemical manufacturer said it would close its industrial site in the Sydney suburb of Rhodes which makes phthalic anhydride and plasticisers.

St George Bank's managing director Jim Sweeney said on Monday that expansion in Victoria was a key strategy and the acquisition of the Bank of Melbourne was an obvious route to pursuing this goal. The report in the Sydney Morning Herald newspaper said St George hoped a poor interim result by the Bank of Melbourne would reduce a takeover price.
* Australia and New Zealand Bank Ltd A$8.29 (+.05)

The bank's managing director, Don Mercer told Reuters that the bank was not worried about the threat of a takeover offer in the aftermath of the Wallis enquiry into Australia's financial system, the results of which are scheduled to be released by the end of March.

Timber planation company posted a a first half net loss of A$16.6 million compared to a profit of A$6.04 million in the previous first half. The loss was after an abnormal loss totalling A$14.75 million which was primarily due to restructuring costs.
Gold miner's stock sagged on Monday after it announced that closed its Telfer mine in Western Australia due to recent cyclonic rains.

The Australian Broadcasting Authority announced on Monday it would offer a second commercial television licence for Western Australia, a move which will break the monopoly of Prime Television's Golden West Network, which Prime acquired from the private interests of Seven Network Ltd's Kerry Stokes late last year, the Australian Financial Review newspaper said.
Clothing manufacturer's shares continued to rise on Monday as rumours swirled the company would shortly be the subject of a takeover offer following recent heavy trading in the company's stock.
The finacial services and property group's shares go ex-dividend today paying an interim dividend of 48 cents per share.
